awd_titl_txt: WORKSHOP: Stanford Institute for Theoretical Economics Summer Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
The Stanford Institute for Theoretical Economics (SITE) summer workshop series offers one of the leading forums for presenting innovative economic theory. SITE workshops bring together top scholars from around the world to highlight and discuss current theories on almost every topic in economics.

The purpose of the SITE summer workshops is to advance economic science for the benefit of society. SITE's mission is to encourage and support the participation of younger scholars as well as provide exposure for scholars and institutions that typically may not be represented at other economics forums. All SITE attendees benefit from opportunities to engage in critical scientific discussion, to gain exposure to new developments in their field and beyond, to promote exchanges across disciplines, and to initiate and collaborate on new research. Attendees bring these assets back to their work and institutions. 

SITE contributes to the understanding and application of economic theory to processes, institutions, and systems, nationally and globally. SITE workshops promote rapid dissemination of the latest, topical research not only to economists but also to researchers, policy-makers and scholars in other disciplines, government and the private sector. To further facilitate dissemination of the knowledge and research, SITE maintains a website where digital versions of the presented papers are available to all. 
SITE facilitates sharing and cross-pollination of theoretical and empirical work on almost every topic in economics, including behavioral and experimental, computational, development, finance, industrial organization, labor, macroeconomics, public, and economic history. Organizers conduct from seven to ten sessions each summer, with an average of 16 presentations and over 40 participants per session. Organizers strive to include research papers in the most active and innovative areas of theoretical economics, as well as under-represented topics. There is also some cohesion along lines of research presented from year to year, reflecting the continuing interests of the organizers.  The goal and contribution of each SITE workshop is to contribute to the dissemination of scientific knowledge, strengthen empirical and theoretical economic analysis and research methods, and improve understanding of the processes and institutions of the US and global economies.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant supports a series of workshops focused on topics of theoretical economics. The series over the last four years has included 8 to 18 workshops annually, running for two or three days each. Workshops are comprised of presentations of in-progress work by economists from institutions around the US and world, with opportunities for discussion and critique. In 2020 and 2021, the sessions were held remotely, which enhanced access to the live presentations, but reduced the ability to network and engage in impromptu discussions.

SITE 2022 was the largest ever - with 18 workshops, 246 presentations, and 756 attendees. Session organizers represented 28 universities and institutions. Organizers selected papers for presentation through a competitive process that in 2022 included 741 submissions. Organizers prioritize choosing presenters from a wide variety of institutions and those who are beginning their careers.

Stanford University has hosted this series of summer workshops in economic theory since 1969. SITE plays a vital role in economic theory development, serving as a renowned forum that attracts top scholars from around the world, bringing together theorists as well as applied economists with an active interest in the theoretical foundations of their work.

SITE gives leading senior investigators, emerging scholars, and students the opportunity to share their research results. The workshop environment promotes interaction, stimulates discussion, and encourages collaboration, leading to research on new topics as well as to new applications of economic theory. SITE's support of younger and underrepresented scholars promotes their professional development with the opportunity to present and receive feedback on their work, as well as to engage with participants ranging from peers to senior scholars. SITE attracts an international and interdisciplinary audience providing an opportunity for diverse scholars to learn from one another and explore questions in other fields. If history is a guide, many presenters will successfully submit their research papers to refereed journals for publication.

SITE benefits greatly from continued support from the National Science Foundation to conduct the workshops and to include a broad, diverse group of participants. NSF funding primarily helps scholars presenting their research with travel costs to the conference.

Over the last several years, many long-standing sessions such as Dynamic Games, Contracts, and Markets and The Macroeconomics of Uncertainty and Volatility have continued, and new sessions have been initiated such as Migration; New Frontiers in Asset Pricing; and Industrial Organization of Healthcare and Consumer Finance Markets. Summaries and programs from each past workshop as well as drafts of some presented papers can be found at https://site.stanford.edu/.


Last Modified: 01/27/2023
Modified by: Alvin Roth
